column6: Orientation to the field of physical therapy history. Functions and responsibilities. Legal and ethical accountability. Patient rights. Safety. Health care delivery system.

column2: PRINCIPLES OF PATIENT CARE IN PHYSICAL THERAPY
column6: Underlying principles of physical therapy procedures. Equipment. Fundamentals of patient care relative to the role of the physical therapist assistant.
Function of the human body with emphasis on the musculoskeletal system. Gross body measurements.

Introduction to medical conditions commonly encountered in the practice of physical therapy which affect the integumentary, digestive and endocrine systems. Will include general medical testing procedures and psychological disorders.
Theory and techniques of treatment procedures with emphasis on modalities. Maintenance of equipment and supplies.

column2: DIRECTED PRACTICE IN PHYSICAL THERAPY I
column6: Introduction to the practice of physical therapy procedures in the clinical setting under the supervision of a licensed physical therapist.
Terminology utilized by the medical profession. Emphasis is on definition, spelling, pronunciation and correct usage of terms.

column4: physical therapist assistant technology (PTST) major and special approval.
column6: Validates prior learning, builds knowledge necessary for the transition to the physical therapist assistant technology (PTST) program and prepares students for advance placement in PTST. Students registering for this course must have successfully completed an approved allied health program and been admitted to PTST. Students successfully completing this course with a grade of C (2.000) or better will receive credit for the following courses: PTST 10002, PTST 10004, PTST 20003, PTST 20004 and PHY 12111.
Introduces clinical education and the essential elements of safe, ethical and legal physical therapy practice in a clinical setting.
Observes and participate in providing selected physical therapy services under the direct supervision of a licensed PT or PTA.
Focus on understanding human behavior. Emotional needs of individuals. Therapeutic use of self. Development of communication skills and interpersonal relationships.
Continued study of medical conditions commonly encountered in the practice of physical therapy. Focus on orthopedic and cardiopulmonary pathologies.
Continuation of theory and techniques of treatment procedures. Emphasis on correlating equipment with treatment procedures and correlating application with dysfunction.

column2: DIRECTED PRACTICE IN PHYSICAL THERAPY II
column6: Discussion and practice of physical therapy procedures and techniques in an institutional setting under the supervision of licensed physical therapy personnel.
Principles and techniques of therapeutic exercise and rehabilitation in physical therapy.

column2: DIRECTED PRACTICE IN PHYSICAL THERAPY III
column6: Continued discussion and practice of physical therapy procedures and techniques in an institutional setting under the supervision of licensed physical therapy personnel.

Continued study of medical conditions commonly encountered in the practice of physical therapy. Focus on geriatric disorders, pharmacology, neurological disorders, fetal development, normal development, genetic and pediatric disorders.

column2: DIRECTED PRACTICE IN PHYSICAL THERAPY TRANSITIONS
column6: Validates prior learning and builds student knowledge of the clinical practice necessary for a physical therapist assistant. An introduction to physical therapy procedures in the clinical setting under the supervision of a licensed physical therapist, and a discussion of the procedures and techniques used in institutional settings. Students completing this course with a grade of C (2.000) or better with receive credit for PTST 10005, PTST 20005 and PTST 20007.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN PHYSICAL THERAPIST ASSISTANT TECHNOLOGY
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Special topics in Physical Therapist Assistant Technology; topics announced when scheduled.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN PHYSICAL THERAPIST ASSISTANT TECHNOLOGY
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Individual study in physical therapist assistant technology and related fields; open to PTST majors.
Explores reimbursement regulations, evidence based practice, and various topics related to physical therapy and the health care system.
Current topics in the practice of physical therapy. Preparation for employment and licensure as a physical therapist assistant.

Athletic Trainers transitioning to physical therapy practice prepare for employment and licensure. Explores reimbursement regulations, evidence based practice, and various topics related to health care systems, and discuss current topics in the practice of physical therapy.

column4: PTST 11005 with a minimum grade of C (2.000); and PTST 11092 with a grade of satisfactory; and special approval.
column6: Provide physical therapy services under the direct supervision of a licensed PT or PTA.

column2: ATHLETIC TRAINING PLUS PHYSICAL THERAPIST ASSISTANT CLINICAL EDUCATION PRACTICUM
column4: PTST 11005 with a minimum grade of C (2.000); and PTST 11092; and special approval.
column6: Provide physical therapy services of an entry-level physical therapist assistant, under the supervision of a licensed PT or PTA.
Provide physical therapy services of an entry-level physical therapist assistant, under the supervision of a licensed PT or PTA.
